sample.title: The Hidden Cost of Oil
sample.description:
Oil sustains South Sudan‚Äôs fragile economy, and for decades, international companies have operated there. But those who live near the oil fields allege pollution has tainted their water, causing miscarriages and birth defects. This Bloomberg investigation examines the evidence in one of the world‚Äôs poorest and most oil-dependent nations.

sample.title: The Infinite Explorer With Hannah Fry Trailer | Premieres Nov. 2
sample.description:
The Infinite Explorer with Hannah Fry seeks out extraordinary local voices and unexpected quirks of history and geography that reveal what makes each place truly unique. With Fry‚Äôs famous curiosity, wit and insight, she peels back the layers of six iconic nations: Spain, Vietnam, Greece, South Korea, Ireland and Iceland.

The all-new series will air Mondays at 8 p.m. ET starting Nov. 2 on Bloomberg Originals, available on major streaming platforms such as Samsung TV+, Prime Video Channels and LG channels. It will also air at 10 p.m. ET on Bloomberg TV and be available on-demand on Bloomberg.com and YouTube.

sample.title: What Gold‚Äôs Rise (Really) Means for the World
sample.description:
Gold‚Äôs price per ounce surged past $4,000 this month, a record-breaking rally tied in part to eroding confidence in the US dollar. Uncertainty driven by Donald Trump‚Äôs trade war as well as questions about the independence of the Federal Reserve and America‚Äôs wavering economy have also played a part. Add to that heightened geopolitical tensions across the globe and you have a recipe for a mass flight to gold. And that‚Äôs exactly what central banks and investors have been doing. 

Now with China seeking to offer an alternative to American dominance, we look at what gold‚Äôs historic rise means for the global financial system. 

Read more: Why Investors Can‚Äôt Seem to Get Enough of Gold
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-10-16/gold-price-record-how-us-china-tensions-fed-cut-bets-are-driving-bullion-rally

Sign up for the Economics Daily newsletter to discover what's driving the global economy and what it means for policy makers, businesses, investors and you.
https://www.bloomberg.com/account/newsletters/new-economy-daily

sample.title: Could AI become conscious?
sample.description:
The societal debate surrounding AI companions isn‚Äôt just about their effects on humans. Increasingly it‚Äôs about whether the companions can have human-like experiences.

In a research paper, titled ‚ÄúTaking AI Welfare Seriously,‚Äù Robert Long, the executive director of Eleos AI, and his colleagues argued that ‚Äúthere is a realistic possibility that some AI systems will be conscious and/or robustly agentic in the near future.‚Äù

sample.title: How Wawa Is Beating Fast Food Companies At Their Own Game
sample.description:
One of America‚Äôs largest convenience store chains, Wawa, has gained a cultlike following in its home markets of Philadelphia and South Jersey due to its sharp focus on food and customer service. Its revenue is estimated to have more than doubled since 2014, and its workforce has grown nearly 90% since 2016 as it rapidly expands to other areas of the country. So, can the nearly $19 billion convenience chain take on major chains and local players like 7-Eleven, Buc-ee's and Casey's General Stores?

4:14 Chapter 2. Rapid expansion

sample.title: How Nike‚Äôs New CEO Plans To Turn Things Around
sample.description:
Nike is the world‚Äôs largest sportswear brand, but after several quarters of disappointing results, its comeback plan is just beginning. Longtime executive Elliott Hill, who came out of retirement to become CEO, says he‚Äôs betting on a ‚Äúreturn to sport‚Äù to revive the brand. In an exclusive interview at Nike‚Äôs Oregon headquarters, Hill tells CNBC‚Äôs Sara Eisen how he‚Äôs reorganizing the company by sport, rebuilding ties with wholesale partners, and reenergizing its innovation pipeline to compete with fast-growing rivals like On and Hoka. But big challenges remain ‚Äî from cleaning up excess inventory to navigating tariffs and a sales slowdown in China. Watch the full story to see how Hill plans to get Nike back on top.

04:10 Returning to Nike

08:38 China

sample.title: Why EVs Depreciate Faster Than Gas Cars
sample.description:
EV‚Äôs are cheaper to operate than a gas car, but their resale values are horrible. It‚Äôs a mix of factors - incentives, changing tech and limited appeal. It‚Äôs a problem for EV adoption, especially as automakers try to attract more mainstream buyers. Here‚Äôs why they can be more expensive to own than a gas car, and why that might change.

sample.title: Why younger Americans are saving money at such a high rate
sample.description:
As Americans live longer and worry about outlasting their money in retirement, a growing number are counting on one strategy for their future financial security: working longer.

Roughly 70% of U.S. workers who haven‚Äôt retired yet have considered pushing back their retirement date, according to a recent survey from F&G, an insurance company. Nearly half of the 2,000 adults surveyed said they‚Äôre afraid they won‚Äôt have enough money to retire.

sample.title: Mark Cuban says PBMs are too powerful but gives Trump credit for tackling drug prices with TrumpRx
sample.description: Cost Plus Co-Founder Mark Cuban is all-in on adding Cost Plus to the TrumpRx platform. In a 30-min exclusive interview with CNBC‚Äôs Bertha Coombs from the HLTH Conference in Las Vegas, he says increasing traffic will help him lower prices so the savings are again passed on to the patient. He discusses his interest in working with legislators at a federal and state level to allow patients to apply any cash they spend on drugs through platforms like his own to their insurance deductible.

sample.title: Life-changing eye implant helps blind patients read again | BBC News
sample.description:
A group of blind patients can now read again after being fitted with a life-changing implant at the back of the eye.
 
A surgeon who inserted the microchips in five patients at Moorfields Eye Hospital in London says the results of the international trial are "astounding".
 
Sheila Irvine, 70, who is registered blind, told the BBC it was "out of this world" to be able to read and do crosswords again. 
 
The technology offers hope to people with an advanced form of dry age-related macular degeneration (AMD), called geographic atrophy (GA), which affects more than 250,000 people in the UK and five million worldwide.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

Zelensky ready to join Trump-Putin talks after ‚Äòfrank‚Äô White House meeting | BBC News
sample.description:
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has said he would be ready to join Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin at a proposed summit in Hungary if he were invited.

The US and Russian presidents announced on Thursday they planned to hold talks on the war in Ukraine in Budapest, possibly in the coming weeks.

In comments released on Monday, Zelensky told reporters: "If it is an invitation in a format where we meet as three or, as it's called, shuttle diplomacy‚Ä¶ then in one format or another, we will agree.‚Äù

Meanwhile, media reports have suggested his White House meeting with Trump on Friday descended into a "shouting match" - with the US side urging Ukraine to accept Russia's terms to end the war.

BBC obtains copy of Virginia Giuffre's memoir | BBC News
sample.description:
Virginia Giuffre said she feared she might "die a sex slave" at the hands of Jeffrey Epstein and his circle, her posthumous memoir revealed. 

The BBC has obtained a full copy of Nobody's Girl, written by the prominent accuser of convicted sex offender Epstein, ahead of its publication on Tuesday - almost six months after she took her own life.

In the memoir, Ms Giuffre also says she had sex with Prince Andrew on three separate occasions, including once with Epstein and approximately eight other young women.

Prince Andrew, who reached a financial settlement with Ms Giuffre in 2022, has always denied any wrongdoing.
